title: Marvel Rivals’ Shocking Layoffs, Netease Responds - Kinda Funny Games Daily 02.19.25

00:22:27 - Xbox’s AI era starts with a model that can generate gameplay
00:33:25 - FromSoftware didn’t want Sony to publish Dark Souls as it was ‘disappointed’ by how Demon’s Souls was treated
00:38:05 - Pokémon Go Developer Niantic Reportedly in Talks to Sell Video Game Business to Saudi-Owned Company Behind Stumble Guys
00:44:16 - Wee News!

book yeah I very much did also I like that you have two of them for like symmetry you know that I wanted to go big for you because it's about stream big and it's about the behind the scenes of twitch and you know I love twitch I bleed purple as you talk about in this book and so yeah I really wanted to go all out for you and kind of talk with you about it and that's how we're going to kind of kick off today's show we're going to have a nice introduction of Nathan then we're going to talk about your books so first off Nathan where are you from where do you write what do you cover what why do you love video games um yeah so currently I write for a site called aftermath um it's reader supported and worker owned um me and a few other people founded it um but before that I've been all over the place um I was at Kotaku for a long time and then after that I was at the Washington Post um and as for why I write about video games uh I grew up playing them and knew that I loved them and always

and let's dive a little bit deeper into what fans can expect if they want to jump in and read your book yeah so the way that I describe it is it's uh kind of the story of twitch as viewed through the lens of nine different streamers some of them are really big names uh that you might have heard of like Assan [ __ ] amaranth dream uh and then some of them are much smaller and I I definitely wanted to have like both ends of that spectrum because I think that you know content creation and streaming are very different experiences depending on how big you are um and so yeah I didn't want to just tell the story of like the platform itself because I think that a lot of people do that their books about YouTube and Tik Tok and you know things like that and they tend to focus on like the companies and the people who like brought the the platform itself to life but while there's an audience for that and while like some people definitely want to know the business side of things I think that

let's have some fun let's talk some video game news story number one Marvel Rivals director and entire Seattle design team laid off net e tells fans not to worry about the game Wesley Yin poool at IGN reports Marvel Rivals developer net e has confirmed cuts to its seattle-based design team for quote organizational reasons end quote overnight Marvel Rivals game director thaddus Sasser took to LinkedIn to an that he and his team were laid off quote this is such a weird industry Sasser began my stellar talented team just helped deliver an incredibly successful new franchise in Marvel Rivals for net East games and we just laid off oh well times are tough all over let's find these incredible people new jobs because we all need to eat right end quote the video game development Community reacted with a mix of shock and anger to the cuts given Marvel rival's explosive success the free-to-play hero shooter has seen over 20 million downloads since the launch in December and a huge peak in

with a model that can generate gameplay this coming from Tom Warren at The Verge today Microsoft's e uh Microsoft's Xbox is unveiling what it's calling a breakthrough in AI for gaming Microsoft's new Muse AI model could help Xbox developers create parts of games in the future and the company says it's even exploring the potential of using it to preserve classic games and optimize them for Modern Hardware Microsoft's research has created Muse a first ofit kind generative AI model that can generate a game environment based on visuals or players control controller actions it understands a 3D game world and game physics and can and can recreate or react to how players interact with the game quote this allows the model to create consistent and diverse game playay rendered by AI demonstrating a major step towards generative AI models that can empower game creators explains fat M Kadar uh corporate vice president of AI at Microsoft The Muse model was trained on a large amount of human

a major step towards generative AI models that can empower game creators explains fat M Kadar uh corporate vice president of AI at Microsoft The Muse model was trained on a large amount of human gameplay data from the Xbox game bleeding edge thanks to the collaboration between Microsoft research and Xbox Studio Ninja Theory both of which are based in Cambridge and the UK this partnership allowed us to closely collaborate with the game Studio to understand what needs to be in place and how we can responsibly unlock access to a large amount of gameplay data says ktia uh Hoffman head of Microsoft's research game intelligence team this allowed Muse to access the equivalent of seven years of human gameplay resulting in the model being trained on a billion image actions action pairs in total Microsoft has released a number of examples of muse model in action generating gameplay and even allowing players to load visual elements into the game to prompt the model this could be used for the

Microsoft has released a number of examples of muse model in action generating gameplay and even allowing players to load visual elements into the game to prompt the model this could be used for the early iteration stages of a game but Microsoft is stressing this isn't designed to generate an entire game and replace creators Microsoft is now exploring how Muse could help improve classic games and bring them to Modern Hardware quote you could imagine a world where from gameplay data and video that a model could learn old games and really make them portable to any platform where these models could run says Microsoft gaming CEO Phil Spencer we've talked about game preservation as an activity for us and these models and their ability to learn completely how a game plays without the necessity of the original engine running on the original Hardware opens up a ton of opportunity end quote the micro Microsoft is also exploring how Muse can help game developers prototype games or how teams
